key_points: Utah Marine Staff Sgt. Taylor Hoover, 31, was among the 13 American troops killed in a suicide bombing near Kabul's airport.
Flags were flown at half-staff in Utah, and more flags lined the street outside Hoover's family home.
The Department of Defense confirmed Hoover's death as Darin T. Hoover; he is often referred to by his middle name, Taylor.
Hoover was remembered by his father, Darin Hoover, as a hero who lived to serve and protect those unable to protect themselves.
Taylor Hoover had served in the Marines for 11 years, leaving behind family and a girlfriend in California.
Gov. Spencer Cox confirmed Hoover's death and honored his devotion and bravery.
Hoover was praised for his leadership qualities and selflessness by friends and family.
Nate Thompson, a childhood friend, described Hoover as a selfless and kind friend with a strong work ethic.
Family and friends mourned Hoover on Facebook, describing him as having a big heart and being a true light to the world.
The suicide bombing attack resulted in the deaths of 11 Marines, a Navy corpsman, and an Army soldier, along with at least 169 Afghan people.
